chunks.cleaned_english_translation: Some, with a greater sense of modesty and respect for the honor of divinity, preferred not to assign any gender to Bythos, so as to avoid the disgrace of even a single marriage being associated with it. Perhaps they use the neuter form to say "This God," rather than the masculine. Others, however, describe it as both male and female, suggesting that the chronicler Fenestella does not believe hermaphrodites exist solely among the people of Luna.
chunks.original_latin:
Pudiciores alii honorem divinitatis recordati, ut
etiam unius conjugii dedecus ab eo avellerent, maluerunt
nullum Bytho sexum deputare: et  fortasse
 Hoc Deum , non Hic Deus, neutro genere
pronuntiant. Alii contra magis, et masculum et foeminam
dicunt, ne  apud solos Lunenses Hermaproditum
existimet Annalium commentator Fenestella.
